Award.AwardTitle: Multifunctional Molecular Interfaces to Metal Oxide Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration: Professor Robert Hamers of the University of Wisconsin-Madison is supported by the Analytical and Surface Chemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry to investigate the use of molecular layers as electronic interfaces to oriented single crystals of TiO2 in the anatase and rutile forms, and extending to other oxides including SrTiO3. Studies will focus primarily on single crystals but will also use nanocrystalline materials as appropriate. The studies are aimed at achieving a fundamental understanding of how differences in surface structure impact the resulting molecular layers and the electronic properties of the interfaces. The structural and electronic properties of these grafted layers on well-defined single crystals of oxide semiconductors will be evaluated using a variety of chemical, structural, electronic, and spectroelectrochemical probes. Oxide semiconductors are the basis for several new and emerging types of dye-sensitized solar cells, quantum dot solar cells, and photocatalysis devices. The ability to integrate these materials with molecular and nanostructured sensitizers could lead to the development of inexpensive solar cells made by simple wet-chemical methods. The educational activities include mentoring of 8th grade students on science projects in renewable energy, summer internships for high school students, and year-round research opportunities for undergraduates and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The formation of interfaces between organic molecules and metal oxides such as titanium dioxide (TiO2) is of importance in emerging technologies such as inexpensive, large-area solar cells.  Organic molecules are very effective at absorbing light, while metal oxides such as TiO2 are effective at separating and conducting electrical charges. The combination of these two is of interest for inexpensive solar conversion.  In this project, new approaches to linking organic molecules to titanium dioxide (TiO2) surfaces were investigated. One approach used ultraviolet light to bond the molecules to the surface. A second new pathway was discovered that allows molecules with aromatic (benzene-like) structures to bind to TiO2, provided that the molecule also has a bromine or iodine atom as part of its structure. These new approaches were investigated both experimentally and computationally.  The molecule-to-oxide connection provided by the second approach has no extraneous intervening atoms and takes place under mild conditions, enabling it to be used with relatively complex molecules having limited thermal stability. The direct molecule-to-oxide linkages provided by both these methods makes them particularly well suited for solar conversion applications. Because the new methods have no known precedent in the chemistry literature, detailed experimental and computational studies were performed to investigate how the reactions depended on details of the molecular structure. Studies were also performed characterizing changes in an ultra-thin water layer that exists on the TiO2 surfaces, and used to help understand the mechanism of surface reactions of TiO2.

The development of new, convenient approaches to forming interfaces between organic molecules and stable oxide semiconductors such as TiO2 may enhance the development of low-cost, environmentally friendly approaches to solar energy conversion.  The project also contributed to the training of graduate students, undergraduate students, high school students, and middle-school students in the conduct of scientific research, and to knowledge dissemination to legislators and the general public. The principal investigator interacted with members of the Wisconsin State Legislature to inform them about properties of nanoscale materials. Project participants facilitated knowledge transfer to K-12 and to the public by developing workshops focusing on electron microscopy imaging of TiO2 and related nanoparticles. Imaging workshops were held for undergraduate students and for visiting students participating in programs targeted toward increasing representation from under-represented groups in science and engineering, providing these students with experience in working with state-of-the-art scientific instrumentation.  Project participants also engaged in science mentoring programs with middle-school and high-school students to provide young students with an understanding of scientific research related to emerging areas of renewable energy.  High-school students participated through a summer science research program hosted by the local school district in which students conducted full-time research during the summer at the university under the direction of the principlal investigator and graduate students.  Webinars on microscopic imaging techniques were created and deposited in a widely used public repository of videos as a way to provide scientific information to the public.
